name.namePart: Estate of Charles W. Warterfield, Jr., F.A.I.A. (Donor)

location.physicalLocation: Special Collections Division of the Nashville Public Library, 615 Church Street, Nashville, Tennessee, 37219

mods.abstract: A photograph of the Rutledge-Baxter House, located at 101 Lea Avenue in Nashville, Tennessee. This historic building rests on the site of "Rose Hill," the grand antebellum home of Henry and Septima Sexta Rutledge, a young couple who were members of the distinguished Rutledge-Middleton families of South Carolina. It was at Rose Hill that the couple frequently entertained such notable friends as Rachel and Andrew Jackson, Sarah and James K. Polk, Sam Houston, and others. Historians believe the Marquis de Lafayette stayed at Rose Hill during his 1825 Tennessee tour. The residence was perched on a knoll overlooking the Cumberland River and featured acres of terraced rose gardens. Circa the 1880's, it was the home of Edmund Baxter, a lawyer and brother of railroad magnate Jere Baxter. Some historians have suggested that Baxter altered the formal, federal style of the home with the addition of an elaborate front porch and a central dome; others credit the addition of the porch to Septima Rutledge. Also, a large portion of the Rose Hill residence was destroyed by fire circa the Civil War. In the 20th century, there were various owners of the property and the building became dilapidated and needed architectural renovation. In 2006, Blackburn & McCune moved their law firm into the Rutledge-Baxter House. The structure is part of Metropolitan Nashville's Rutledge Hill Redevelopment District. Photographed by the Nashville architect Charles Wesley Warterfield, Jr. (1926-1998); the architectural photograph forms part of the Charles Warterfield Architectural Collection. Gift of: The Estate of Charles W. Warterfield, Jr., F. A. I. A. The original is a 35 mm color transparency (2 x 2 in. slide mount).
